item.title: Introduction
item.description: Introduction Technology in the classroom can help the learner make deeper connections with the material being taught. However, we need to ensure that we choose technologies that enhance the educational experience and do not hinder it. These tools should also fit our pedagogy and allow us to apply proven learning techniques. This site looks at three technologies and assesses then potential use in the classroom. The technologies chosen were Jupyter Notebooks, Padlet and HackMD.

item.title: Padlet
item.description: Padlet Overview Padlet is collaboration tool for collecting articles, videos, music, text and photos on a online virtual bulletin board. Padlets allow for multiple users to simultaneously add, read and organize matters usually based on a central theme or idea. The materials can be organized in different formats though the most common seems to use columns to further break down the overall idea into subtopics. Homepage: padlet.com Platform: MacOS or Online (accessed via browser)

item.title: HackMD
item.description: HackMD Overview HackMD is a collaborative online editor for Markdown files. Markdown is a simplified markup language that allow you to quickly format your documents while you write. HackMD provides an editor tailored for Markdown that provides live rendering of the formatting as you type. The site also allows for multiple users to work on the document simultaneously. Website Link: hackmd.io Platform: Online (There is also a standalone application supported on Windows, MacOS and Linux)

item.title: Jupyter Notebooks
item.description: Jupyter Notebooks Overview Jupyter Notebooks is an open-source web application that can be used to produce and share documents that include a mixture of text, live code examples, equations, and visualization. These can be used in many fields as live teaching documents that embed examples the students can run themselves or modify and run to expand their understanding of the topic. They are commonly used in courses to illustrate data science, scientific simulation or to teach software development itself.
